>
Subject: 
Re: [DKIM Failure] Diligent credit
Credit memo was offset against an invoice: #1
7240330
 (11/21/22) and #
17240330 rev 
(4/1/23)
 
Duplicate pmt should have been posted as unapplied pmt on customers acct in 2022. Instead a credit memo was created in 2022 which hit revenue with deposit posted to deferred revenue. 
So overall AR balance was correct but deferred revenue and revenue was not. I corrected AR with 1/1/23 JE by debiting Deferred revenue and crediting A/R. 
However, this also required me to delete credit memo from Nov22 on 1/1/23 but couldn’t since we couldn’t change 2022 or Q1. To get things correct YTD I still need to cancel impact of credit memo but on 4/1/23.
 
To cancel impact of Nov22 credit memo,  I created invoice 
17240330 rev
 
dated 4/1/23 and applied Nov22 vendor credit 17240330 against this new invoice. AR aging now just shows credit of $12885 for Diligent from JE which represents credit on customer’s account from duplicate payment. Nothing in deferred revenue, cash is correct and sales net zero between the two years. 
 
If you would prefer I can reverse the JE dated 1/1/2 on 4/1/23 but if so then deferred revenue and sales will still need corrected with another JE. Typically speaking, duplicate payments are not handled with credit memos but usually come though on deposit transactions. We can’t alter the 11/1/22 deposit transaction however so a JE is the best we can do or else I have to create a fictitious deposit which I don’t want to do since it involves cash. I have T accounts on this to prove my logic but unable to scan to send to you right now. 
 
Rosie

Jennifer and Alisa,
 
Hope all is well.  Attached is a 12-31-2022 preliminary draft.  We still have to go through our final review process but I wanted to give you a chance to review so you can provide any potential questions or changes.  Please note, there are still some open items.  We will not be able to finalize until we receive the following:
 
AR information as requested so we can finish our analytics as related to an allowance for doubtful accounts.
Interest rate, terms, etc on the line of credit.  I will send Nick an email.
Bank waiver from Nick.
 
Once you have reviewed the preliminary draft and we have done a final review once receiving the open information, we will send a revised draft with our management rep letter.  Once the rep letter is signed and returned, we can finalize.

As always, please reach out with any questions.

Dear Chuck & Maria,
 
As we discussed in our meeting on Wednesday, I’m writing to remind you all about the bonus commission plan presented to our team on 4/28/23 by Jennifer and Alisa that went into effect on April 1.   While my team did not receive formal documentation through Zenefits, I am attaching screenshots of what was presented along with the notes outlined below. Jeniffer previously shared calculations in spreadsheet format; however, I do not have a copy of the most recent version. Nevertheless, here I am attaching a copy of an early version, and I include a summary of both what was told to the team and the current status of proposals:
 
Summary of Bonus Structure Plan:
 
Proposal Production
BD Proposal team will be eligible for quarterly bonuses based on proposal production.
Quarterly Bonus Payout will be paid one month after the quarter ends
The BD team’s targeted number of proposals is 180/per year
The BD has a quarterly proposal production target of 45 per quarter.
If the BD team collectively meets 75% of their goal of 45 per quarter (34 proposals), they are eligible for a bonus payout on the proposals created
The bonus Structure is as follows:

subject: Grace Vottero Will be Terminated from Language & Culture Worldwide on June 16th, 2023
body:
We've received your request to terminate Grace Vottero on 06/16/2023. Don't worry, we won't send them any communication. 
Here's what Zenefits will take care of:
Payroll: We'll mark Grace for termination in payroll on 
06/16/2023
, and continue to pay them unless you manually remove them. Issue their last pay check by running termination payroll. 
Not sure how? 
We recommend you understand 
your state's specific final paycheck requirements 
to remain compliant with the law. 
Here's what you need to take care of:
 
Final Payment: Each state has a different law regarding when a company must give terminated employees their final paychecks. Please refer to the Final Paycheck law for NJ to find out when you have cut this employee's final paycheck. We recommend that you confirm the final amount you owe Grace with your payroll provider before cutting the check. 
Paid Time Off: New Jersey law does not require you to pay employees for their unused PTO upon termination. However, if you wish to pay out employees for unused PTO, you'll want to add $1,346.92 to their final paycheck. 
Termination & Severance Paperwork: If your company uses any termination forms, you'll want to get the individual to sign them and you'll want to 
add the signed documents here
 for future reference. 
If you have any questions or concerns feel free to 
contact us.
 
Thanks,
Zenefits
For more information or assistance, please visit 
help.zenefits.com
.

subject: FW: Reference for Redd
body:
Here is the latest reference response for Redd (Virtas).
 
From:
 Michael Dorfman <Mdorfman@buyawg.com> 
Sent:
 Thursday, June 15, 2023 1:53 PM
To:
 Jennifer Barbieri <j.barbieri@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Patricia Pinter <ppinter@buyawg.com>
Subject:
 RE: Reference for Redd
 
Jennifer,
 
Please see below and reply.
 
What was the scope of the project (debt refinance, strategic restructuring etc.) that was provided to your firm? Redd was instrumental in a process to restructure the company financial debt mechanism after the departure of a prior CFO to assist the company in redefining its next tier of performance under high growth planning. He supported the management initiatives to develop debt restructuring options, looking initially at 20 financial company options, and honing to a more concentrated set of 6 with formal processes. This included detailed assessment of financial flow of funds using an intense spreadsheet model that included both historical results and then used a combination of predictive analytics, management judgement working with an expert executive team, and strategic plans the company had in place to chart the next few years of anticipated budget and results within the framework of optimized use of newly restructured debt models. 
How well did Virtas meet your requirements and expectations? This was very timely and important step for the company to move to the next level of funding at that time for the business. 
How well did Virtas remain within the original budget and timeline? Yes. Adjustments were discussed and agreed upon as our needs changed. We were happy with the results.
How satisfied were you with the skill level of the Virtas team on the engagement? We would recommend this service to others needing short term consultative assistance in times of a gap or need for new expertise.
Please share any additional information that you think is helpful to us as we continue to review other consulting firms.  Redd is a very capable and talented expert at ABL credit lines and debt restructuring. He has built excellent networks in those bank divisions and can assist companies nicely with similar situations. 
 
Regards,
.
Michael Dorfman
CEO
American Wire Group
P
 954-455-3050 ext. 201 | 
M
 305-469-4544
E
 
mdorfman@buyawg.com
 | 
www.buyawg.com
2980 NE 207th Street Suite PH
Miami, FL 33180 United States

subject: Re: Reference for Redd
body:
Thank you, Michael, for your quick reply.
Jennifer 
Sent from my iPhone
On Jun 15, 2023, at 1:53 PM, Michael Dorfman <Mdorfman@buyawg.com> wrote:
﻿
 
Jennifer,
 
Please see below and reply.
 
What was the scope of the project (debt refinance, strategic restructuring etc.) that was provided to your firm? Redd was instrumental in a process to restructure the company financial debt mechanism after the departure of a prior CFO to assist the company in redefining its next tier of performance under high growth planning. He supported the management initiatives to develop debt restructuring options, looking initially at 20 financial company options, and honing to a more concentrated set of 6 with formal processes. This included detailed assessment of financial flow of funds using an intense spreadsheet model that included both historical results and then used a combination of predictive analytics, management judgement working with an expert executive team, and strategic plans the company had in place to chart the next few years of anticipated budget and results within the framework of optimized use of newly restructured debt models. 
How well did Virtas meet your requirements and expectations? This was very timely and important step for the company to move to the next level of funding at that time for the business. 
How well did Virtas remain within the original budget and timeline? Yes. Adjustments were discussed and agreed upon as our needs changed. We were happy with the results.
How satisfied were you with the skill level of the Virtas team on the engagement? We would recommend this service to others needing short term consultative assistance in times of a gap or need for new expertise.
Please share any additional information that you think is helpful to us as we continue to review other consulting firms.  Redd is a very capable and talented expert at ABL credit lines and debt restructuring. He has built excellent networks in those bank divisions and can assist companies nicely with similar situations. 
 
Regards,

subject: References for consultants
body:
Virtas Partners – reference for Tim Czmiel & Redding ("Redd") Thomas
Spoke with Alex Parish
Used Virtas with many times in different capacities – interim CFO, due diligence for acquisitions, restructuring bank debt (great bank relationships), QofE
Great in middle markets sector
Put in systems, reporting and training
Expensive but Good
They stayed on time and on budget
Highly satisfied with their skill levels and professionalism.
 
Sutker Moran – reference for Scott Moran
Spoke with Bert Hodapp
CFO was a “train reck” and they engaged Suker to act as an interim approx. 5 years ago and just ended the engagement last month
Used them over the years in less scope over time as they rehired an internal role
They stayed on time and on budget
Highly satisfied with their skill levels and professionalism. Bert liked them as people and is somewhat sad not working with them anymore.
 
Newport Advisors – reference for Matt Brash
Spoke with Terrell Williams
Newport helped refinancing in the midst of the pandemic, and helping to improve cash flow planning.
Had a very positive experience. Met expectations and continue to work with them now in a lesser capacity
They stayed on time and on budget
Highly satisfied with their skill levels and professionalism
They interviewed four or five groups before deciding.  All seemed to have their own agendas or were so in bed with our then-lender that it felt uncomfortable.  NP has never felt like that.  They help when they can, they’re available as needed, and they get out of the way the rest of the time.
 
KFK – reference for Kevin Kelly
Spoke with John Quattrocchi 
Their COO died suddenly in August last year. KFK filled the CFO role and assisted in operations.
Instrumental in restructuring, debt finance and the sale of one of their divisions.
They stayed on time and on budget
Highly satisfied with their skill levels and professionalism
Would not be in a solid position without KFK
------------------------------------------------------
Jennifer Barbieri
LCW 
100 S Saunders Rd, Suite 150
Lake Forest, IL 60045

On Wed, Jun 14, 2023 at 10:42 AM Redding Thomas < 
rthomas@virtaspartners.com
> wrote: 
Morn Beth - 
 
Reaching out directly to see how your "process" was shaping up.  I saw Tim's email with the Virtas full-rate price card and a couple of attorney references - but not sure if you two have discussed actual terms and discounted pricing. 
 
Like I mentioned on the call, I work with Virtas as an independent 1099 consultant.  They bring me in as a specialist on critical engagements and we share fees.  Essentially, I do 100% of the work and as such have a lot of influence with regard to terms/pricing.  My published Virtas rate ($700) is excessive for the type of ground work and cumulative hours needed for this engagement.  A more appropriate rate would be 55-65% of that number (or equivalent fixed fee) depending on committed hours.   
 
So let me know if you want to discuss pricing or anything else further.  I can liaison with Tim/Virtas and make sure we pull together something reasonable.  I don't want to see both of us priced out of an opportunity to work together.
 
 
In addition - I've got additional recent client/customer references that sing my praise. 
 
Regards -  
 
Redd 
646-662-5660

Subject: 
Setting up Vendor Profile - Inter-American Development Bank
Hello Jennifer,
 
I hope you are having a nice Wednesday so far!
 
Could you please help us get our account set up in Inter-American Development Bank’s vendor profile? The instructions they shared are below. We are ready to invoice them so I’m hoping we can get set up as soon as possible – is today too optimistic? What do you think? I am available to support however I can!
 
Thanks,
Grace
 
Please note that firms can register their accounts and request access to the vendor portal through the following link 
https://vendorportal.iadb.org
 
and clicking on 
“Request vendor account (Firms only)” 
located under the Need Help Section.
 
If you have firms with active purchase orders that you work with, we can help them with the onboarding process. Please fill out the attached template and send it back to 
idbvendorportaladmin@iadb.org
; and we will contact them directly.

subject: Accepted: Monthly All Staff Meeting
Thank you
body:
Hello Jennifer and Beth,
 
 
 
First off, thank you for the opportunity today to speak with you and learn more about 
Language & Culture Worldwide, LLC I
 appreciate you taking the time to discuss the opportunity of Controller. I know my diverse accounting background coupled with my ability to learn quickly will be a great asset to your team. My in-depth knowledge of excel including VLOOKUP and pivot table will assist your company with product costs analysis.  I have 12 years of strong financial analysis and accounting experience that makes me the right person for this position.  I look forward to hearing from you. Please let me know if you have any additional questions. 
 
 
Thank you, 
 
Pedro Henriquez
518-322-7631
Sent from my iPhone

Thank you!

subject: Reference questions for Newport Advisors
body:
Hi Terrell – thank you for the quick reply. Here are some of the questions we had for you. Please feel free to call me if it’s easier for you. Otherwise an email is suffice. 
 
What was the scope of the project (debt refinance, strategic restructuring etc) that was provided to your firm?
How well did Newport meet your requirements and expectations?
How well did Newport remain within the original budget and timeline? 
How satisfied were you with the skill level of the Newport team on the engagement?

 Thursday, June 8, 2023 2:49 PM

 Briza Cardenas <b.cardenas@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: Stack ranking, next steps and references
 
Hi Briza – do we have references for Scott Moran?
 
Thank you,
Jennifer
 
From:
 Briza Cardenas <
b.cardenas@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Monday, June 5, 2023 11:21 PM
To:
 Jennifer Barbieri <
j.barbieri@lcwmail.com
>
Cc:
 Alisa Kolodizner <
a.kolodizner@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 FW: Stack ranking, next steps and references
 
Hi Jennifer, 
Below you will find Beth’s first impressions stack-rank. I’ve also included all of Beth’s notes below that.
 
Here are my consolidated thoughts and tentative first-impressions stack-rank:
Tim Czmiel & Redding ("Redd") Thomas (Virtas Partners Rate Card attached) --> Know their stuff; we would be super small for them; not sure who we would get (they have 43 employees); made some comments that they might be able to make some introductions 
Scott Moran --> Good if considering CFO / CCO pieces as well; would be a well-oiled machine; could be more integrated; would need to look at pricing
Kevin Kelly --> Independent and would do 80% of the work himself; fit would really matter so Alisa should screen
Recommended next steps:
Get pricing schedule from each
Meet with referrals of each (I am not able to do this timely; someone else will need to)
Alisa to meet with Kevin to determine fit
Compare pricing and benefits
References
 
Tim Czmiel References
Martin Carroll, Chairman of Fox Swibel law firm in Chicago.  His email is 
mcarroll@foxswibel.com
 and his phone number is 312-224-1230. 
Alex Parrish of Honigman.  Alex is head corporate attorney for his law firm and has a national practice.  His phone number is 313-465-7512 and his e-mail is 
aparrish@honigman.com
. 
 
Kevin Kelly References attached.
References for Matthew Brash (Guy Alisa met with)
Leslie H – 414-241-7699
Tom T – 224-330-7889
Terrell – 303-638-6413
 
From Beth:
Below are my notes and thoughts from today's "
Wintrust Recommendation: Scott Moran & LCW"
 meeting with Scott Moran.  FYI, his contact information is as follows:  (815) 404-3811; 
smoran@sutkermoran.com
; 
www.sutkermoran.com
.
 
OVERALL:  Strong consider; price-dependent
 
IMPRESSION:
Reasonable; liked approach and philosophy.  This is likely not the person that you would work with, so hard to say with who you would work with.
NOTES / OBSERVATIONS:
Work with profitable and distressed businesses; can be hands on or hands off.  Commonality is needs more labor for their firm.
Can play a permanent CFO or CCO role in a company as well (do this for over 50 companies)
#1 is have discussions with leadership with goal to get to know the business and nuances of the business early.  Seek to understand the culture.
#2 is understanding the forecast that we have in place; focus on that first.  Putting the projection together and verifying assumptions and mapping it out.
#3 from there, we have articulated the plan, communicated with the bank, will need to monitor.  What changes are we making, from there what does that projection tell us and what do you need and how can we help?  Sometimes there is not additional resources needed, some just need help laying it out and that is it.  Then they can help communicate with the bank.  
Note:  "we work for you guys, not the bank."  They just introduced us. 
Revenue --> growing and diversifying their revenue.  Most of those permanent engagement...can be CFO and / or CCO.  As examples, in service and construction (50% of customers); project based environment with a fixed labor pool.  Understanding the backlog and matching that up and right-sizing personnel is important. 
Challenging and working with the leadership to come up with ideas and working with them to come up with ideas.  See what is working and not working and amplifying that.  
Interim or permanent CFO roles that they can fill --> "roll up our sleeves type firm, not a PPT firm."  Permanent or interim CFO and CCO options.  Statardize close, forecast, projections, etc. Training firm members and deploying to the companies they work with.  They can do that on a fixed-fee basis (agree on tasks and guaranteed for a fixed fee).  
Retention rates / ability to speak to current services customer --> Can speak to current customers.  They will include fees and references in his follow-ups.  Consider for multiple seats (at least in the interim).
Below are my notes and thoughts from today's "
Wintrust Recommendation: Kevin Kelly & LCW
" meeting.
 
OVERALL:  Could be good; more flexible and more willing to be piecemeal and willing to consider different scopes.  The first between management and Kevin will be very important, so that should be sussed out before going further.  Can help with CFO / CCO quality, but does not supplement those roles in the way the prior firm can.
 
IMPRESSION:
Owns his own firm; does 80%+ of the work himself (have to really like him)
Willing to cater to us and what we need
Aligned to the business
Charge by the hour and can be efficient (can help with scope and good with estimation); can tell with a range on where we might end up
$350 / hour
NOTES / OBSERVATIONS
Background.  Chicago native.  Went into public accounting.  Was a partner.  [Went on tangents].  Worked in management consulting.  Been out on their own since 2019.  Has two individuals, but 80%+ of the work he does himself.  
Middle market focus; small to incredibly large.  Lots of experience.  Worked with 450+ closely held companies.  Implement best practices and strategic planning.  Operationalize, professionalize, streamline, etc.  Accounting background drives him to focus on profitability.  
"Always' creates more value than his fee.  Work for the business, directed by the company.  Fiduciary duty would be to the ownership of LCW.  
Keep liquidity.  Have worked with every lending institution across everything (investment banking background).  Have been lucky and good and tend to get referred (2/3 bank) and (1/3 board members / CEOs).  If you have liquidity; first goal is to get to profitability.  The covenants can be rest.  Two different opposing forces.  The originators vs the credit group that is paid to worry; helping them understand the plan so they can be placated.
On growing revenue.  Been in consulting 37+ years of his life.  Have worked with companies tangentially in this space (HR consulting, etc.).  The spend in this area can be the first go go; there is a process by which I would understand and challenge the current business development and marketing goals (strategy, lead time, pipeline, are we measuring that performance, etc.)  This is talking about process improvement for revenue, versus helping in business development (generally expected for this space).  
Getting to business development and how doing targeting marketing.  Is there a finder's fee.
Superpowers --> business practices that they have implemented and successfully brought online at companies (100s of times and in growth and distressed); the experience on navigating the gamut is his secret superpower (aka, seen it all ; deep experience).  There is a concern about our numbers.  That skillset is easy for him to come in and understand.
Work well with people.  Understanding the environment and recommend things that are able to be implemented.  Bank thinks highly of the business and Alisa.  Hasn't been a good articulation of the plan or they have not believed it.
Needs:  timely information; access to the right people in a timely way; opportunity to build consensus; candor; be thoughtful on how we explain their role to the rest of the team
Willing to do piecemeal and take work that the team has done (and that he vets). 
Below are my notes and thoughts from today's "
Tony Wilkins Recommendation: Tim Czmiel & LCW
" meeting.
 
OVERALL:  I liked them; very knowledgeable and had the relationships needed.  Need to determine if we can actually afford them (we are small for them).
 
IMPRESSION:
Seem to be very experienced.  Seemed to be slightly condescending, but would ask you to stress test that yourself.  Have experience in the area.  Unclear on their alignment to business versus the bank.
NOTES / OBSERVATIONS:
They know the bank and the people there
Two people
(1) would need to request a waiver of the covenant and will want a tight look on cash flows and projections
Superpower:  where we shine is they know us, we come in and everyone takes a deep breath and gives us a chance to take a look and give some reassurance that nothing is on fire and not hidden time bombs and then we shine in terms of running projections and cash flows (waivers; restructuring; taking them out and bringing someone else in)
(2) help with decreasing expenses and increasing revenue; this is their "bread and butter"; everything mentioned is routine.  A bit more difficult than realize to get the covenant waiver; need the cash flow model(rolling) and then a cadence with the loan officer with some company representative.  Give them the overview of what time is needed to put together financial statements and rationalize the business ("one of the biggest mistakes people make is to get out the hatchet too early
LCW is on the very, very low side of what they do (as in super small compared to what they do).  Banks require independent third parties to do this work.  Lost confidence in the CFO; they would no longer be the point person with dealing with the bank (That would be Redd).  Goal to get to real data and real information.
Worked with over 100 operating companies.  
Build trust between the company and the lending institution.  Depending on the severity of the situation, they don't just give a covenant waiver...they will need to see a tactical plan (not a strategic plan)...accounting, finance, sales, and operations...what are you going to do in each?
Helps that they know Wintrust.  Get us a chance to get to know numbers and the management and then report back.  Establish credibility.  
Will send a rate sheet (might have to revise a bit because we are so small).  Will share referrals.  
Tim --> can't tell you how many times over the years I have gotten a call "small town USA" there have been so many...why?  To see these individuals; save jobs is Tim's motivation.  Giving hope and saving jobs.  
Redd --. I have a hero complex.  I love to come in a challenging situation that is rigorous and coming out on top.  We have never not succeeded.  
Company of 43 people; unclear who we would be working with.  We know consulting and know how to build a business.  Has no debt and designed that way.  Question on if we are too small for them.
First is stabilization and getting things calmed down.  Lenders would love to see 3 years of projections.  They want to see what you are going to do, sensitivity analysis, do they want to stick with you or not.  Needs a growth plan.  need to be in alignment with the financial projection.
Needs to be a meeting after a RIF (reduction in force) to have a script, this is what happened, why, etc.
Bankers will want a variance report with a rolling 13 week model.  
 
Briza Cardenas
(she/her/hers)
Chief of Staff, Office of the CEO

Hi Jennifer, 
Below you will find Beth’s first impressions stack-rank. I’ve also included all of Beth’s notes below that.
 
Here are my consolidated thoughts and tentative first-impressions stack-rank:
Tim Czmiel & Redding ("Redd") Thomas (Virtas Partners Rate Card attached) --> Know their stuff; we would be super small for them; not sure who we would get (they have 43 employees); made some comments that they might be able to make some introductions 
Scott Moran --> Good if considering CFO / CCO pieces as well; would be a well-oiled machine; could be more integrated; would need to look at pricing
Kevin Kelly --> Independent and would do 80% of the work himself; fit would really matter so Alisa should screen
Recommended next steps:
Get pricing schedule from each
Meet with referrals of each (I am not able to do this timely; someone else will need to)
Alisa to meet with Kevin to determine fit
Compare pricing and benefits
References
 
Tim Czmiel References
Martin Carroll, Chairman of Fox Swibel law firm in Chicago.  His email is 
mcarroll@foxswibel.com
 and his phone number is 312-224-1230. 
Alex Parrish of Honigman.  Alex is head corporate attorney for his law firm and has a national practice.  His phone number is 313-465-7512 and his e-mail is 
aparrish@honigman.com
. 
 
Kevin Kelly References attached.
References for Matthew Brash (Guy Alisa met with)
Leslie H – 414-241-7699
Tom T – 224-330-7889
Terrell – 303-638-6413
 
From Beth:
Below are my notes and thoughts from today's "
Wintrust Recommendation: Scott Moran & LCW"
 meeting with Scott Moran.  FYI, his contact information is as follows:  (815) 404-3811; 
smoran@sutkermoran.com
; 
www.sutkermoran.com
.
 
OVERALL:  Strong consider; price-dependent
 
IMPRESSION:
Reasonable; liked approach and philosophy.  This is likely not the person that you would work with, so hard to say with who you would work with.
NOTES / OBSERVATIONS:
Work with profitable and distressed businesses; can be hands on or hands off.  Commonality is needs more labor for their firm.
Can play a permanent CFO or CCO role in a company as well (do this for over 50 companies)
#1 is have discussions with leadership with goal to get to know the business and nuances of the business early.  Seek to understand the culture.
#2 is understanding the forecast that we have in place; focus on that first.  Putting the projection together and verifying assumptions and mapping it out.
#3 from there, we have articulated the plan, communicated with the bank, will need to monitor.  What changes are we making, from there what does that projection tell us and what do you need and how can we help?  Sometimes there is not additional resources needed, some just need help laying it out and that is it.  Then they can help communicate with the bank.  
Note:  "we work for you guys, not the bank."  They just introduced us. 
Revenue --> growing and diversifying their revenue.  Most of those permanent engagement...can be CFO and / or CCO.  As examples, in service and construction (50% of customers); project based environment with a fixed labor pool.  Understanding the backlog and matching that up and right-sizing personnel is important. 
Challenging and working with the leadership to come up with ideas and working with them to come up with ideas.  See what is working and not working and amplifying that.  
Interim or permanent CFO roles that they can fill --> "roll up our sleeves type firm, not a PPT firm."  Permanent or interim CFO and CCO options.  Statardize close, forecast, projections, etc. Training firm members and deploying to the companies they work with.  They can do that on a fixed-fee basis (agree on tasks and guaranteed for a fixed fee).  
Retention rates / ability to speak to current services customer --> Can speak to current customers.  They will include fees and references in his follow-ups.  Consider for multiple seats (at least in the interim).
Below are my notes and thoughts from today's "
Wintrust Recommendation: Kevin Kelly & LCW
" meeting.
 
OVERALL:  Could be good; more flexible and more willing to be piecemeal and willing to consider different scopes.  The first between management and Kevin will be very important, so that should be sussed out before going further.  Can help with CFO / CCO quality, but does not supplement those roles in the way the prior firm can.
 
IMPRESSION:
Owns his own firm; does 80%+ of the work himself (have to really like him)
Willing to cater to us and what we need
Aligned to the business
Charge by the hour and can be efficient (can help with scope and good with estimation); can tell with a range on where we might end up
$350 / hour
NOTES / OBSERVATIONS
Background.  Chicago native.  Went into public accounting.  Was a partner.  [Went on tangents].  Worked in management consulting.  Been out on their own since 2019.  Has two individuals, but 80%+ of the work he does himself.  
Middle market focus; small to incredibly large.  Lots of experience.  Worked with 450+ closely held companies.  Implement best practices and strategic planning.  Operationalize, professionalize, streamline, etc.  Accounting background drives him to focus on profitability.  
"Always' creates more value than his fee.  Work for the business, directed by the company.  Fiduciary duty would be to the ownership of LCW.  
Keep liquidity.  Have worked with every lending institution across everything (investment banking background).  Have been lucky and good and tend to get referred (2/3 bank) and (1/3 board members / CEOs).  If you have liquidity; first goal is to get to profitability.  The covenants can be rest.  Two different opposing forces.  The originators vs the credit group that is paid to worry; helping them understand the plan so they can be placated.
On growing revenue.  Been in consulting 37+ years of his life.  Have worked with companies tangentially in this space (HR consulting, etc.).  The spend in this area can be the first go go; there is a process by which I would understand and challenge the current business development and marketing goals (strategy, lead time, pipeline, are we measuring that performance, etc.)  This is talking about process improvement for revenue, versus helping in business development (generally expected for this space).  
Getting to business development and how doing targeting marketing.  Is there a finder's fee.
Superpowers --> business practices that they have implemented and successfully brought online at companies (100s of times and in growth and distressed); the experience on navigating the gamut is his secret superpower (aka, seen it all ; deep experience).  There is a concern about our numbers.  That skillset is easy for him to come in and understand.
Work well with people.  Understanding the environment and recommend things that are able to be implemented.  Bank thinks highly of the business and Alisa.  Hasn't been a good articulation of the plan or they have not believed it.
Needs:  timely information; access to the right people in a timely way; opportunity to build consensus; candor; be thoughtful on how we explain their role to the rest of the team
Willing to do piecemeal and take work that the team has done (and that he vets). 
Below are my notes and thoughts from today's "
Tony Wilkins Recommendation: Tim Czmiel & LCW
" meeting.
 
OVERALL:  I liked them; very knowledgeable and had the relationships needed.  Need to determine if we can actually afford them (we are small for them).
 
IMPRESSION:
Seem to be very experienced.  Seemed to be slightly condescending, but would ask you to stress test that yourself.  Have experience in the area.  Unclear on their alignment to business versus the bank.
NOTES / OBSERVATIONS:
They know the bank and the people there
Two people
(1) would need to request a waiver of the covenant and will want a tight look on cash flows and projections
Superpower:  where we shine is they know us, we come in and everyone takes a deep breath and gives us a chance to take a look and give some reassurance that nothing is on fire and not hidden time bombs and then we shine in terms of running projections and cash flows (waivers; restructuring; taking them out and bringing someone else in)
(2) help with decreasing expenses and increasing revenue; this is their "bread and butter"; everything mentioned is routine.  A bit more difficult than realize to get the covenant waiver; need the cash flow model(rolling) and then a cadence with the loan officer with some company representative.  Give them the overview of what time is needed to put together financial statements and rationalize the business ("one of the biggest mistakes people make is to get out the hatchet too early
LCW is on the very, very low side of what they do (as in super small compared to what they do).  Banks require independent third parties to do this work.  Lost confidence in the CFO; they would no longer be the point person with dealing with the bank (That would be Redd).  Goal to get to real data and real information.
Worked with over 100 operating companies.  
Build trust between the company and the lending institution.  Depending on the severity of the situation, they don't just give a covenant waiver...they will need to see a tactical plan (not a strategic plan)...accounting, finance, sales, and operations...what are you going to do in each?
Helps that they know Wintrust.  Get us a chance to get to know numbers and the management and then report back.  Establish credibility.  
Will send a rate sheet (might have to revise a bit because we are so small).  Will share referrals.  
Tim --> can't tell you how many times over the years I have gotten a call "small town USA" there have been so many...why?  To see these individuals; save jobs is Tim's motivation.  Giving hope and saving jobs.  
Redd --. I have a hero complex.  I love to come in a challenging situation that is rigorous and coming out on top.  We have never not succeeded.  
Company of 43 people; unclear who we would be working with.  We know consulting and know how to build a business.  Has no debt and designed that way.  Question on if we are too small for them.
First is stabilization and getting things calmed down.  Lenders would love to see 3 years of projections.  They want to see what you are going to do, sensitivity analysis, do they want to stick with you or not.  Needs a growth plan.  need to be in alignment with the financial projection.
Needs to be a meeting after a RIF (reduction in force) to have a script, this is what happened, why, etc.
Bankers will want a variance report with a rolling 13 week model.  
 
Briza Cardenas
(she/her/hers)

From Beth:
Below are my notes and thoughts from today's "
Wintrust Recommendation: Scott Moran & LCW"
 meeting with Scott Moran.  FYI, his contact information is as follows:  (815) 404-3811; 
smoran@sutkermoran.com
; 
www.sutkermoran.com
.
 
OVERALL:  Strong consider; price-dependent
 
IMPRESSION:
Reasonable; liked approach and philosophy.  This is likely not the person that you would work with, so hard to say with who you would work with.
NOTES / OBSERVATIONS:
Work with profitable and distressed businesses; can be hands on or hands off.  Commonality is needs more labor for their firm.
Can play a permanent CFO or CCO role in a company as well (do this for over 50 companies)
#1 is have discussions with leadership with goal to get to know the business and nuances of the business early.  Seek to understand the culture.
#2 is understanding the forecast that we have in place; focus on that first.  Putting the projection together and verifying assumptions and mapping it out.
#3 from there, we have articulated the plan, communicated with the bank, will need to monitor.  What changes are we making, from there what does that projection tell us and what do you need and how can we help?  Sometimes there is not additional resources needed, some just need help laying it out and that is it.  Then they can help communicate with the bank.  
Note:  "we work for you guys, not the bank."  They just introduced us. 
Revenue --> growing and diversifying their revenue.  Most of those permanent engagement...can be CFO and / or CCO.  As examples, in service and construction (50% of customers); project based environment with a fixed labor pool.  Understanding the backlog and matching that up and right-sizing personnel is important. 
Challenging and working with the leadership to come up with ideas and working with them to come up with ideas.  See what is working and not working and amplifying that.  
Interim or permanent CFO roles that they can fill --> "roll up our sleeves type firm, not a PPT firm."  Permanent or interim CFO and CCO options.  Statardize close, forecast, projections, etc. Training firm members and deploying to the companies they work with.  They can do that on a fixed-fee basis (agree on tasks and guaranteed for a fixed fee).  
Retention rates / ability to speak to current services customer --> Can speak to current customers.  They will include fees and references in his follow-ups.  Consider for multiple seats (at least in the interim).
Below are my notes and thoughts from today's "
Wintrust Recommendation: Kevin Kelly & LCW
" meeting.
 
OVERALL:  Could be good; more flexible and more willing to be piecemeal and willing to consider different scopes.  The first between management and Kevin will be very important, so that should be sussed out before going further.  Can help with CFO / CCO quality, but does not supplement those roles in the way the prior firm can.
 
IMPRESSION:
Owns his own firm; does 80%+ of the work himself (have to really like him)
Willing to cater to us and what we need
Aligned to the business
Charge by the hour and can be efficient (can help with scope and good with estimation); can tell with a range on where we might end up
$350 / hour
NOTES / OBSERVATIONS
Background.  Chicago native.  Went into public accounting.  Was a partner.  [Went on tangents].  Worked in management consulting.  Been out on their own since 2019.  Has two individuals, but 80%+ of the work he does himself.  
Middle market focus; small to incredibly large.  Lots of experience.  Worked with 450+ closely held companies.  Implement best practices and strategic planning.  Operationalize, professionalize, streamline, etc.  Accounting background drives him to focus on profitability.  
"Always' creates more value than his fee.  Work for the business, directed by the company.  Fiduciary duty would be to the ownership of LCW.  
Keep liquidity.  Have worked with every lending institution across everything (investment banking background).  Have been lucky and good and tend to get referred (2/3 bank) and (1/3 board members / CEOs).  If you have liquidity; first goal is to get to profitability.  The covenants can be rest.  Two different opposing forces.  The originators vs the credit group that is paid to worry; helping them understand the plan so they can be placated.

Getting to business development and how doing targeting marketing.  Is there a finder's fee.
Superpowers --> business practices that they have implemented and successfully brought online at companies (100s of times and in growth and distressed); the experience on navigating the gamut is his secret superpower (aka, seen it all ; deep experience).  There is a concern about our numbers.  That skillset is easy for him to come in and understand.
Work well with people.  Understanding the environment and recommend things that are able to be implemented.  Bank thinks highly of the business and Alisa.  Hasn't been a good articulation of the plan or they have not believed it.
Needs:  timely information; access to the right people in a timely way; opportunity to build consensus; candor; be thoughtful on how we explain their role to the rest of the team
Willing to do piecemeal and take work that the team has done (and that he vets). 
Below are my notes and thoughts from today's "

" meeting.

Subject:
 Controller Interview Questions
 
Hello everyone,
 
Here are the question I’ve received so far for the Controller interviews scheduled for tomorrow and Monday. Please let me know if you’d like me to add anything else to this list. 
Experience & Background Questions:
Tell me about the most challenging financial project you’ve ever worked on.  What was your role?  What happened and what was the result?
Tell me about a time when you needed to set up accounting/financial reporting controls.  What was your role?  What happened and what was the result?
Please walk through a time when you have improved the quality of financial information or the efficiency of sharing financial information.  What was your role?  What happened and what was the result? 
What kind of accounting/financial reporting software do you use frequently? 
Knowledge Questions:
What's the first factor or element to consider when managing a budget development initiative? 
Please walk through a time you identified a financial opportunity for your company.   What was your role?  What happened and what was the result? 
What are the financial strengths and weaknesses you see in LCW's space?  What opportunities do you see in the space and where would you start identifying financial opportunities for LCW?
Management & Leadership Questions:
How would people who have worked with you describe your management style?
Tell me about a time when you needed to give a complex assignment to someone on your team.  What was it?  What did you do?  What happened and what was the result?
Recall a time you had to present an important financial decision to your executive team where you and the executive team disagreed.  What was your role?  What happened and what was the result? 
Continuous Improvement Questions:
Please tell me about a time when you made processes or reporting more efficient.  What was your role?  What happened and what was the result? 
 
Thank you,

I would recommend we empty out both the invoice and Scoro and the invoice in QB – and then generate 2 new invoices and re-sync them to QB.  Modifying in Scoro and then syncing to QB may or may not work as intended – and once an invoice in Scoro is linked to an invoice in QB, it’s gets hard (apparently) to separate them.
 
So, remove the deliverables from the invoice in Scoro and make them billable again. Void out the invoice in QB.  Re-create 2 new invoices in Scoro and sync both to QB – and then submit normally.
 
Thx,
R

I believe that she had two invoices (17240180 for $43,500 and 17240300 for $57,750) that she told Sarah had been set to “Ready to Invoice” only to find out later that they hadn’t been (I think this was the David period). Since then RL has determined that they want them billed in different amounts to two new PO that they raised in their Ariba portal to split the costs across profit centers.
 
$73,250 – RL CorpUSA
$28,000 – RL Europe Sarl Switzerland
 
 
The question I had was does it make more sense to delete the two old invoices and create new ones to submit in the Ariba portal? What impact would that have in Compass or QBO? 
 
Does that help clarify?
 
Chuck

Hello everyone,
 
Here are the question I’ve received so far for the Controller interviews scheduled for tomorrow and Monday. Please let me know if you’d like me to add anything else to this list. 
Experience & Background Questions:
Tell me about the most challenging financial project you’ve ever worked on.  What was your role?  What happened and what was the result?
Tell me about a time when you needed to set up accounting/financial reporting controls.  What was your role?  What happened and what was the result?
Please walk through a time when you have improved the quality of financial information or the efficiency of sharing financial information.  What was your role?  What happened and what was the result? 
What kind of accounting/financial reporting software do you use frequently? 
Knowledge Questions:
What's the first factor or element to consider when managing a budget development initiative? 
Please walk through a time you identified a financial opportunity for your company.   What was your role?  What happened and what was the result? 
What are the financial strengths and weaknesses you see in LCW's space?  What opportunities do you see in the space and where would you start identifying financial opportunities for LCW?
Management & Leadership Questions:
How would people who have worked with you describe your management style?
Tell me about a time when you needed to give a complex assignment to someone on your team.  What was it?  What did you do?  What happened and what was the result?
Recall a time you had to present an important financial decision to your executive team where you and the executive team disagreed.  What was your role?  What happened and what was the result? 
Continuous Improvement Questions:
Please tell me about a time when you made processes or reporting more efficient.  What was your role?  What happened and what was the result?

How would people who have worked with you describe your management style?
Tell me about a time when you needed to give a complex assignment to someone on your team.  What was it?  What did you do?  What happened and what was the result?
Recall a time you had to present an important financial decision to your executive team where you and the executive team disagreed.  What was your role?  What happened and what was the result? 
Continuous Improvement Questions:
Please tell me about a time when you made processes or reporting more efficient.  What was your role?  What happened and what was the result? 
 
Thank you,
Maria Mercado, SPHR, SHRM-SCP
